content.text: Place the mass \(\mathbf{X}\) on the rule so that its centre is at a distance \(d = 5.0 \text{cm}\) from the zero end of the rule, as shown in Fig. 1.1. Record the value of \(d\) in Table 1.1
Adjust the position of the rule so that it is as near as possible to being balanced, with the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the right of the pivot
Measure, and record in the table, the distance \(\mathbf{x}\) from the centre of the mass \(\mathbf{X}\) to the pivot
Measure, and record in the table, the distance \(y\) from the pivot to the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule
Repeat the steps (i) â€“ (iv) using \(d = 10.0 \text{cm}\)
Using the values of \(\mathbf{x}\) and \(\mathbf{y}\) in the first row of the table, calculate the mass \(M\) of the rule using the equation
Repeat step (b)(i) using the values of \(x\) and \(y\) in the second row of the table
Calculate the average value of \(M\)
average value of \(M =\)   .........
Method 2.
Measure the mass \(M\) of the rule using the balance provided
A student carrying out this experiment expects that the values of the mass \(M\) obtained by the two methods will be exactly the same
Suggest two practical reasons why, in spite of following the instructions with care, the values may differ. Assume that the balance used in Method 2 is accurate
Explain briefly how you judge the position of the centre of the mass \(\mathbf{X}\) when it is
rule in **(a)(iii)**. You may draw a diagram
In this experiment, you will determine the mass of a metre rule using two methods
**Method 1.**
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
You are provided with a \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass, labelled \(\mathbf{X}\)
Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{C}}\) of the cold water supplied

Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the beaker of water. When the thermometer reading stops rising, measure the temperature \(\theta\) of the water in the beaker and immediately start the stopclock. In Table 2.1, record \(\theta\) at time \(t = 0 \text{s}\)
In the table, record the temperature of the water at 30s intervals until you have a total of six values up to time \(t = 150 \text{s}\)
Empty the beaker. Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
the thermometer in the beaker of water. When the thermometer reading stops the measure the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the water in the beaker
Pour \(10 \text{cm}^3\) of the cold water into the beaker of hot water. Stir briefly. Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the water
Pour another \(10 \text{cm}^3\) of the cold water into the beaker of hot water. Stir briefly. Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{2}\) of the water

Using the evidence that you have from the table and the readings in parts (c) and (d), estimate the volume \(V\) of cold water that added to the hot water would give the same temperature drop as allowing the hot water to cool for 150 s. Explain briefly how you arrived at your answer
This laboratory investigation could be used as a small-scale model for a process in a factory. The laboratory investigation would be repeated many times
Suggest two conditions that should be kept constant in order to provide reliable results
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water
You are provided with a supply of hot water and a supply of cold water. Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Place the lens a distance \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. Move the screen until a sharply focused image of the object is seen on the screen
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the height \(h\) of the image on the screen
Repeat the steps in **(a)** and **(b)** using \(u\) values of \(30.0 \text{cm}\), \(35.0 \text{cm}\), \(40.0 \text{cm}\) and \(45.0 \text{cm}\)
Calculate, and record in the table, the values of \(\frac{1}{h}\)
Plot a graph of \(u / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(\frac{1}{h} /\frac{1}{\text{cm}}\) (\(x\)-axis). You do not need to begin the at the origin (0,0)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens, using the equation \(f = \frac{G}{1.5} \text{cm}\). Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a lens
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
Switch on. Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across lamp 1 and the current \(I\) in the circuit. Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of lamp 1 using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I}\)
Disconnect the voltmeter and reconnect it to measure the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across lamp 2
Disconnect the voltmeter and reconnect it to measure the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across lamp 3
Calculate the total potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{T}}\) across the three lamps using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{T}} = V_{1} + V_{2} + V_{3}\)
Complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 4.2 to show the three lamps in parallel
each other between \(\mathbf{P}\) and \(\mathbf{Q}\). Show the voltmeter connected to measure potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) across the lamps. Use standard symbols
Disconnect the lamps and the voltmeter. Rearrange them to make the circuit shown in your circuit diagram
Switch on. Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) across the lamps and the total current \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\). Switch off
Calculate the total resistance \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the lamps arranged in parallel, using the
equation \(R_{\mathrm{p}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{p}}}{I_{\mathrm{T}}}\)
A student suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) should be equal to \(\frac{R_{1}}{3}\)
State whether your results support this suggestion and justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification

Another student suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) may not be equal to \(\frac{R_{1}}{3}\) because the lamp filaments are hotter when the lamps are connected in parallel than when the lamps are connected in series
State one piece of evidence that shows that the lamp filaments are hotter in the parallel circuit
In this experiment, you will investigate lamps in series and parallel combinations
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 4.1
